title: 108_hr2763
content: The Act titled "Public Private Vocational Partnership Act of 2003" allows for donations to high schools and community colleges for vocational education purposes under section 45G of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. The vocational education donation credit for corporations is determined by 90% of the fair market value of qualified property donations and the intern credit amounts. There are limitations on the credit amount, with a maximum of $50,000 for property donations and $100 per month for each qualified intern. The taxpayer can receive a credit for qualified property donations and intern expenses, with a maximum credit of $6,000 per intern. Qualified property donations must be made to educational organizations for use within the United States for educational purposes. The taxpayer can receive a credit for qualified property donations and intern expenses, with a maximum credit of $6,000 per intern. Qualified property donations must meet specific criteria, including fitting into the donee's education plan and meeting minimum functionality standards for educational purposes. A qualified intern is defined as a full-time student in high school or community college. A qualified intern for the taxpayer is a full-time student in high school or community college, employed for up to 20 hours per week as part of an approved vocational education course. High school refers to a secondary education institution offering vocational education, while a community college is a postsecondary institution providing a 2-year program acceptable for credit towards a bachelor's degree. The text discusses the aggregation rule for determining a single employer under certain sections and the coordination with Section 170(b) for reducing limitations on taxable year credits. Additionally, it mentions the amendment to the general business credit section of the tax code. The text discusses amendments to the tax code related to vocational education donation credits for corporations and rules regarding the carryback of such credits. Additionally, it addresses the denial of double benefits for certain expenses. The tax code amendments include a new subsection for vocational education donations, reducing the deduction allowed for amounts under section 45G by the credit determined under section 45G(a). A conforming amendment is made to the table of sections for subpart D of part IV of subchapter A of chapter 1. The tax code amendments introduce a new deduction for donations to high schools and community colleges for vocational education purposes, effective for taxable years starting after December 31, 2002.
